conclusion: There are objects casting shadows (A, B, and C) on a surface.
A light source is illuminating these objects and casting the shadows.
Shadows A, B, and C are initially cast to the right of the objects.
The light source moves to the right above the objects.

premise: When the light source moves to the right, it changes the angle at which light hits the objects.
conclusion: This shift in angle causes the direction of the shadows to change.

premise: The direction of the shadows changes due to the shift in angle of the light source.
conclusion: Shadows will now shift to the left of the objects.

premise: The size of shadows is influenced by the angle of the light source relative to the objects.
conclusion: As the light source moves to the right, the shadows become shorter and smaller.

premise: Shadows shift to the left and become shorter and smaller as the light source moves to the right.
conclusion: Shadows A, B, and C will shift to the left and become shorter and smaller.
